_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Omaha Steaks International
9203 F Street
Omaha, NE
Ammonia Refrigeration System 

Accidental release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Omaha Steaks is strongly committed to the safety of its employees, the general public, and the surrounding environment.  This commitment is demonstrated not only through the daily actions of its management staff and employees, but also through the comprehensive accidental release prevention program Omaha Steaks has in place.  This program covers areas such as system design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and contractor and employee training associated with the ammonia refrigeration process at our facility.  Omaha Steaks makes every effort to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of anhydrous ammonia, and as such, releases are not foreseeable, however, Omaha Steaks' Emergency Action Plans are fully coordinated with the emergency response personnel at the Omaha Fire department and their associated HAZMAT Team to control and mitigate the effects of any release.

The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

Omaha Steaks F Street Plant is a meat processing facility located in Omaha, NE.  The stationary source at tis facility is a closed-loop, ammonia refrigeration system using anhydrous ammonia.   All the anhydrous ammonia stored on-site is used in the closed loop, ammonia refrigeration system. 

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps.

Omaha Steaks has taken all necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements of both 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA, commonly referred to as RMP, and 29 CFR 1910.119 of OSHA, commonly known as PSM.  This compliance is achieved through a unified PSM/RMP program at Omaha Steaks.  The Omaha Steaks F Street Plant is also subject to the notification requirements found in EPCRA Section 302.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the Omaha Steaks PSM/

RMP Program.

Employee Participation
Omaha Steaks believes that accident prevention is a team effort; our employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements to make our covered process safer.  In addition, all Omaha Steaks employees have access to all information collected as part of the facility compliance with the PSM/RMP rules.

Process Safety Information
Omaha Steaks maintains a detailed record of written safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters, and equipment and system designs associated with the ammonia refrigeration system.

Process Hazard Analysis
Omaha Steaks conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our refrigeration system are identified and controlled efficiently.  The current methodology in use at Omaha Steaks is the checklist methodology.  These studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering, process operation, and regulatory compliance.  These studies will be revalidated every 5 years, or sooner if required by the associated regulation.  Any findings related to the PHA are addressed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures
Omaha Steaks maintains written Operating Procedures for all activities associated with the covered process.  These written procedures address the various modes of operation including initial start-up, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and start-up after a turn around.  These procedures are regularly reviewed and is readily available to operators involved with the refrigeration system.

Training
Omaha Steaks has a comprehensive program in place to ensure that any of its employees working on the refrigeration system are competent in the operating procedures for the tasks they are preforming.  Omaha Steaks also has an equally comprehensive program to verify the training of all con

tractor employees that are operating the system, and that those contract employees are competent in the tasks they are hired to complete.  Refresher training on the Operating Procedures and other Safe Work Practices occur at least every three years and more frequently if needed or required by additional regulatory standards.

Contractors
Omaha Steaks hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities related to the ammonia refrigeration system.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance and policies is carried out.  Additionally, Omaha Steaks has a strict policy of informing contractors of any known potential hazards associated with their work, emergency response procedures in relation to the accidental release of ammonia, and the procedures to properly access our facility.

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews
Omaha Steaks has an established practice of requiring a pre-startup safety review be conducted whenever there is the introduction of a new process, changes are made to an existing process, or whenever a section of the refrigeration system has been isolated for maintenance.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that the equipment, materials, and operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for a safe startup prior to placing equipment on-line for operation. 

Mechanical Integrity
Omaha Steaks documents all testing, calibration, and maintenance activities on all equipment in and associated with the covered process, ensuring safe and proper operations.  These activities are preformed by qualified personnel that have been provided with specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies noted in these activities are corrected in a safe an timely manner.

Hot Work Permit Program
Omaha Steaks has a robust Hot Work Permit program covering all hot work activities performed on or around the covered process to help maintain process integrity and facility fire prevention safety.

Managem

ent of Change
Written policies and procedures are in place at Omaha Steaks to manage all changes to chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures affecting the covered process.  Refrigeration system operators, maintenance, personnel and all other employees whose job tasks are affected by a change are notified of the change prior to the start of the change and are provided any necessary training to maintain their safety as well as the safety of the covered process due to the change.

Incident Investigation
Omaha Steaks promptly investigates, at a minimum, any incident that has, or could reasonably have, resulted in a catastrophic release of anhydrous ammonia.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the events leading up to the incident, the effectiveness of the response to the incident, and any corrective actions that will prevent future incidents of the same type from occurring.  All documentation from these investigations are maintained for a minimum of 5 years. 

Compliance Audits
Omaha Steaks conducts audits of the PSM/RMP program every three years to determine if the provisions set forth under the PSM/RMP regulations are being effectively implemented.  Any corrective actions required as a result of these audits are addressed in a safe and timely manner.

Five-Year Accident History
Due to its stringent release prevention policies, Omaha Steaks has had an excellent record of zero accidental releases during the past five years.

Emergency Response Plan
Omaha Steaks has a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The policy of Omaha Steaks is to participate in an emergency response in an advisory role only, relying instead, upon the trained responders from LoTemp Refrigeration and the Omaha Fire Department and its associated Haz-Mat Team.  The emergency response plant at the Omaha Steaks F Street facility is coordinated with both LoTemp Refrigeration and the Omaha Fire Department and its associa

ted Haz-Mat Team. Omaha Steaks an emergency action plan in place to properly prepare for emergency evacuations, provide first aid and medical treatment as needed, and to contact federal, state, and local officials in the event of a major release of ammonia.

The Omaha Fire department and its associated Haz-Mat Team and the Douglas County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) are the agencies with which our emergency plan have been coordinated and verified.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Through the ongoing implementation of the PSM/RMP program and its elements, Omaha Steaks looks continuously for possible ammonia refrigeration system changes to improve the safety of our employees, the surrounding community, and the surrounding environment.
